unnormalised: Someone asked me, “What's the best way to donate to charity in India without getting scammed?" Well, bhai, that’s a question even RBI struggles with! Seriously though, figuring out where your hard-earned ₹500 or ₹5,000 (or even a cool Rs. 50,000 if you're feeling generous after that bonus!) goes is important.
normalised: Someone asked me, “What is the best way to donate to charity in India without getting scammed?" Well, bhai, that is a question even R-B-I struggles with! Seriously though, figuring out where your hard-earned rupee five hundred or rupee five thousand (or even a cool rupees fifty thousand if you are feeling generous after that bonus!) goes is important.

unnormalised: First things first, do your homework! Don't just blindly throw money at that random guy with a sad puppy picture and a UPI ID. Check if the charity is registered under Section 80G of the Income Tax Act. If they are, your donation is tax-deductible! Score! That's like getting a mini refund on your good deed. Websites like GiveIndia or Charities Aid Foundation are good starting points 'cause they’ve already vetted a lot of organizations.

Check if the charity is registered under Section eighty G of the Income Tax Act. If they are, your donation is tax-deductible! Score! That is like getting a mini refund on your good deed. Websites like GiveIndia or Charities Aid Foundation are good starting points because they have already vetted a lot of organizations.

unnormalised: Now, about those scams… Sigh. They're like mosquitoes during monsoon season in Mumbai - relentless! Be wary of organizations asking for donations in crypto or gift cards - red flag! Also, look out for high administrative costs. If 80% of your Rs. 100 donation is going towards "office supplies" and the CEO's chai bill, something's fishy.

unnormalised: Ultimately, donating should feel good! If you’re not sure, start small, say Rs. 100, and see how transparent they are. Do they provide updates on how the money was used? Remember, even a little bit helps. And if all else fails, just feed a stray dog a packet of biscuits – instant good karma for approximately ₹10! You can't go wrong there, unless you're allergic. Then maybe donate that Rs. 10 to the dog biscuits fund on your behalf!
